**Case Summary: Vinay Kumar GB vs. Sudhir Kumar and Anr.**

**Background:**
The case involves a dispute between Vinay Kumar GB, the proprietor of Insights IAS and Insights Active Learning, and Sudhir Kumar, the proprietor of Insight IAS Academy. The case is related to intellectual property rights, specifically trademark infringement. There are multiple connected matters, including C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 244/2021, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 245/2021, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 342/2021, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 395/2021, and CS(COMM) 779/2022.

**Legal Issues:**
The main issue in this case is whether the rejoinders filed by the petitioners (Vinay Kumar GB) can be taken on record, given that they were filed beyond the time stipulated in Rule 7(x) of the Intellectual Appellate Division (IPD) Rules, 2002.

**Arguments:**
Mr. Jayant Kumar, the learned counsel for the respondent (Sudhir Kumar), argued that the rejoinders filed by the petitioners were filed beyond the maximum period of 30 days prescribed in Rule 7(x) of the IPD Rules. He contended that the use of the word "shall" in the rule forecloses the right of the petitioner to file a rejoinder once the maximum period has expired.

**Court Findings:**
The court examined Rule 7(x) of the IPD Rules, which requires the rejoinder to be filed "within the period prescribed by the Court or within 30 days from the date on which the Court directs the filing of such rejoinder." The court noted that the learned Joint Registrar had directed the filing of the rejoinder on September 12, 2022, without stipulating a specific period. The court observed that the rule requires the rejoinder to be filed within a maximum period of 30 days from the date of the direction.

**Decision:**
The court ultimately decided to allow the rejoinders to be taken on record, despite being filed beyond the 30-day period. The court's decision is not explicitly stated in the provided text, but it can be inferred that the court did not accept Mr. Jayant Kumar's argument that the use of the word "shall" in Rule 7(x) forecloses the right of the petitioner to file a rejoinder once the maximum period has expired.

**Implications:**
The court's decision suggests that the IPD Rules should be interpreted in a manner that allows for flexibility and does not unduly restrict the rights of parties to file rejoinders. The decision may have implications for future cases involving intellectual property disputes and the interpretation of the IPD Rules. However, the exact reasoning and implications of the court's decision are not fully clear from the provided text and would require further analysis of the entire judgment.

Sudhir Kumar and Anr.pdf", the Court rules that the rejoinder filed beyond 30 days from the date of filing of the written statement can be taken on record. The Court rejects the objection of Mr. Jayant Kumar, citing that the IPD Rules do not explicitly state that a rejoinder cannot be filed after 30 days. The Court decides to take the rejoinders on record in cases CO (COMM. IPD-TM) 244/2021 and CO (COMM. IPD-TM) 245/2021. The cases are then referred to mediation by the Delhi High Court Mediation and Conciliation Centre, as both parties believe an amicable resolution is possible. The decision was made on February 20, 2023, and digitally signed by Sunil Singh Negi. (Source: 46. Vinay Kumar GB v. Sudhir Kumar and Anr.pdf, page 14)

conspicuously absent in Rule 7(x) of the IPD Rules.  The Court 
cannot, by judicial fiat, read, into Rule 7(x) of the IPD Rules, the 
words “but not thereafter” which, though consciously employed in 
Rule 5 of Chapter VII of the Original Side Rules, do not find place in 
Rule 7(x) of the IPD Rules.  Further, the consequence of non payment 
of costs imposed in terms of Rule 5 of Chapter VII of the Original Side 
Rules, cannot be made, by extrapolation, to apply to non filing of a 
rejoinder within the time stipulated in Rule 7(x) of the IPD Rules.   
 
20. 
Even for this reason, it is not possible for the Court to, by 
relying on Rule 5 of Chapter VII of the Original Side Rules, hold that 
the rejoinder, filed beyond the period of 30 days envisaged by Rule 
7(x) of the IPD Rules, cannot be taken on record. 
 
21. 
For these reasons, the objection of Mr. Jayant Kumar, to the 
effect that as the rejoinder in CO (COMM. IPD-TM) 244/2021 and 
CO (COMM. IPD-TM) 245/2021 were filed beyond 30 days from the 
date of filing of written statement, they cannot be taken on record, 
fails. 
 
22. 
No other objection, to the taking on record of the said 
rejoinders, was raised by Mr Jayant Kumar. 
 
23. 
As such the rejoinders filed in CO (COMM. IPD-TM) 244/2021 
and CO (COMM. IPD-TM) 245/2021 are taken on record. 
 
24. 
Both sides submit that if this dispute is referred to mediation, 
there may be a possibility of an amicable resolution. As such, these 
cases are referred to mediation by the Delhi High Court Mediation and 
Conciliation Centre.

nodes.summary: According to page 15 of the PDF "46. Vinay Kumar GB v. Sudhir Kumar and Anr.pdf", the High Court of Delhi has ordered the parties to attend the High Court Mediation and Conciliation Centre on February 20, 2023, to fix a schedule for mediation. The court has also directed that the matter be re-notified on April 13, 2023, to ascertain the outcome of the mediation. The order was passed by Justice C. Hari Shankar on February 16, 2023. The case involves Vinay Kumar GB as the plaintiff and Sudhir Kumar and another as defendants, represented by their respective advocates. The court's decision aims to facilitate mediation and potentially resolve the dispute amicably. (Source: 46. Vinay Kumar GB v. Sudhir Kumar and Anr.pdf, page 15)
